review.title: Rediscovering the Alphabet - On the Innate Universal Grammar
review.abstract: Universal Grammar (UG) theory has been one of the most important research topics in linguistics since introduced five decades ago. UG specifies the restricted set of languages learnable by human brain, and thus, many researchers believe in its biological roots. Numerous empirical studies of neurobiological and cognitive functions of the human brain, and of many natural languages, have been conducted to unveil some aspects of UG. This, however, resulted in different and sometimes contradicting theories that do not indicate a universally unique grammar. In this research, we tackle the UG problem from an entirely different perspective. We search for the Unique Universal Grammar (UUG) that facilitates communication and knowledge transfer, the sole purpose of a language. We formulate this UG and show that it is unique, intrinsic, and cosmic, rather than humanistic. Initial analysis on a widespread natural language already showed some positive results.

metadata.title: On the Innate Universal Grammar

sections.text: The theory of Universal Grammar (UG) has been one of the most important research topics in linguistics since its introduction five decades ago. UG specifies the limited number of languages that can be learned by the human brain, and therefore many researchers believe in their biological roots. Numerous empirical studies of neurobiological and cognitive functions of the human brain and many natural languages have been carried out to reveal some aspects of UG. However, this has led to different and sometimes contradictory theories, which do not show a universally unique grammar. In this research, we approach the UG problem from a completely different perspective. We are looking for the Unique Universal Grammar (UG), which facilitates communication and knowledge transfer, the only purpose of a language. We formulate this UG and show that it is unique, intrinsic and cosmic and non-humanistic.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: Humans have an inherent need to answer questions and understand the universe. Throughout human civilization, philosophers and scientists have been able to answer - or at least speculate on - many basic questions, such as: Where did life come from? What is the age of the universe? How did it all start? And many others. However, one question has long puzzled humans: Language. They say language is the most important evolutionary contribution of humans to the cosmos and perhaps the most interesting feature that has emerged in the last 500 million years (Nowak et al. 2002). How did it all begin? Was language genetically inherited from other species? Do we even share language with other species? And how is language constructed from its basic building blocks? All of these questions can be answered if we define language rigorously.

sections.heading: Language and Universal Grammar
sections.text: A language is a set of sentences; a sentence is a string; and an alphabet is a finite set of symbols. Some languages are finite and some are not. There are infinite finite languages, as many as whole numbers. There are also infinite languages, as many as real numbers. Therefore, the set of all languages is not countable (Nowak et al. 2002). A grammar is a finite set of rules that specify a language. Natural languages are infinite. However, learning theory and common sense suggest that no algorithm can learn a set of languages (Nowak et al. 2002). sections.text: Most living beings strive for immortality. At the cellular level, impregnation is considered a process of communication in which knowledge or information, DNA and RNA stored in chromosomes are exchanged. This biological language has only a four-letter alphabet and is capable of generating all complex life forms. We believe that language is a process of communication in which knowledge or information, DNA and RNA stored in chromosomes are exchanged. This biological language has only a four-letter alphabet and is capable of generating all complex life forms. Since language is a process of communication, basic rules governing language apply, these rules are what defines universal grammar (UG). Methods of communication in nature range from chemical compounds in insects to air vibrations (sounds) and signals in human beings. The process of communication is independent of the principles that we understand as the Medium (UG).

sections.heading: From Communication to Universal Grammar
sections.text: Nouns are the most important parts of the language, and usually the naming process is non-descriptive, i.e. we use any code or idiom to name a particular object. That's what we do most of the time when we name our children, we use arbitrary names. Also, when we transfer a word from one language to another, we also use arbitrary names, and the transferred word becomes an idiom. Nevertheless, a language is exhausted with all idiomatic nouns. Man will have to memorize an extensive dictionary when that language is a little rich and intelligible. As the main purpose of any language is to facilitate simple and precise communication, the easier way is to give each object a descriptive name, i.e. to define that object from a short list of known, already defined objects; just as we do in numerical systems.

sections.heading: Conclusion and Future Remarks
sections.text: In this paper, we have introduced a new formal definition of Universal Grammar (UG). Instead of researching the human brain, natural languages, genetics, history and psychology for a UG, we decided to go another way and look for the basic logic behind an UG and a language that is communication and knowledge transfer. We developed a theory for communication and knowledge dissemination through language. This theory offers a rigorous mathematical definition of UG that coincides well with many other great theories in physics, astronomy, philosophy, mathematical logic and informatics. Thus, we were able to fully analyze, decipher and understand every language governed by this unique UG. After formulating our UG and what we call the digital alphabet, we set out to search for the possibility of any natural language that meets our UG requirements. By a stroke of luck, our first study with Arabic was so far positive.
